title: How to Make Egg Drop Soup

steps.headline: Bring the broth or stock to a rolling boil.
steps.description: This should be done in either a deep saucepan or wok. Use whichever tool you are most comfortable with, since using a saucepan instead of a wok will not affect your end results.

steps.headline: Mix in the salt and white pepper.
steps.description: This is also the time to add the sesame oil, if you plan on using it.

steps.headline: Continue cooking the soup for another minute, and then turn off the heat.
steps.description: Turning off the heat will allow the eggs to reach a desirable "silky" texture.

steps.headline: Slowly pour in the eggs.
steps.description: Create the "shredded" egg look by straining the eggs slowly into the soup through a fork or chopsticks while simultaneously whisking them with your other hand. The fork or chopsticks should be held between eight and ten inches above your saucepan. To make the eggs look like ribbons instead of shreds, stir the eggs clockwise but do it at a slow, steady, and controlled rate. Be careful not to let the egg streams touch too much, since this will cause unattractive clumping and rubbery eggs.

steps.headline: Garnish your creation with onion or chow mein noodles, once the eggs have formed (meaning they are completely cooked).

Garnish your creation with onion or chow mein noodles, once the eggs have formed (meaning they are completely cooked). Serve hot.
